name.text: 15.2.1.4 Calculating centre of mass rod with 2 masses

questiontext.text:
Exercise

Objects of mass \(m\) and \(3m\) are placed at the locations shown in diagram (a). Find the distance \(\bar{x}\) of the centre of mass from the origin \(O\) as illustrated in diagram (b).

First calculate the sum of the individual moments: [[input:ans1]][[validation:ans1]] \( \textrm{kg}\, \textrm{m}\) [[feedback:prt1]]

The moment of the total mass about \(O\) is \(4 m \times \bar{x}\).

The moment of the total mass is equal to the sum of the moments of the individual masses. What equation do we get by equating the two moments?

[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] \(\times \; m = \) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] \(\times \; m\bar{x}\)

So what is the distance \(\bar{x}\)?
\(\bar{x}=\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]] [[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
The sum of the individual moments is: \(6\times m + 10 \times 3m = 36m.\)

Equating the two moments gives: \(36m = 4m\bar{x}\). And thus \(\bar{x}=\frac{36m}{4m}=9.\)

So the centre of mass is located a distance 9 units along the \(x\)-axis. Note that it is closer to the position of \(3m\) mass than to the position of \(1m\) mass (actually in the ratio 3:1).

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
